GameItemType.Description: This axe is crafted with the highest quality metal and crystal, and enchanted with cold magic that withers the enemy when struck.

GameModifier.Provides: Backswing- If the attack misses the unit gets a second attack against the same target

UnitType.Backstory: Snow Giants were once a rarity, considered myth amongst common folk. These days however sightings are not uncommon, as the arctic wastes and snow covered mountains that the Snow Giants once called home are now all but gone - forcing the Snow Giants to search the lands for suitable locations to reestablish themselves.

Snow Giants were once a rarity, considered myth amongst common folk. These days however sightings are not uncommon, as the arctic wastes and snow covered mountains that the Snow Giants once called home are now all but gone - forcing the Snow Giants to search the lands for suitable locations to reestablish themselves.

Normally reclusive and mild-tempered, bears are territorial creatures, and relentless when disturbed. Despite their nature, their sheer size and strength make them deadly.
Recall the story of Samman the Gentle Bear, in Erwynn's Tales, and how he pursued the Bandit Boy of Amin Fer all across the plains of Engar to retrieve the berries the boy had stolen from him. The wise traveler learns to avoid the forest and hillsides these creatures call home.

Wargs are fell creatures, wolves mutated by dark magics thousands of years ago. They are stronger and more cunning than their non-magical counterparts. They prefer to hunt alone, and will fight over territory rather than ally themselves with their brethren.
The Ice Warg is characterized by its whitish-gray pelt and affinity for cold regions.

UnitType.Quote: We are primitive, but not powerless.
UnitType.Backstory: These are a primitive and violent people, said by some to be a sub-race of the Fallen, shaped by Curgen in those same years in which the Urxen were first formed. They are cave dwellers, preferring cold and artic climates. By darklings standards they are not particularly malicious and given the proper incentive, they will form alliances of a sort.

UnitType.Quote: We are primitive, but not powerless.
UnitType.Backstory: These are a primitive and violent people, said by some to be a sub-race of the Fallen, shaped by Curgen in those same years in which the Urxen were first formed. They are cave dwellers, preferring cold and artic climates. By darklings standards they are not particularly malicious and given the proper incentive, they will form alliances of a sort.

UnitType.Quote: It has shinies. Maybe we can take the shinies from it.
UnitType.Backstory: A select few Frostling warriors are chosen for the honor of becoming Warg riders; these are not necessarily the strongest or most powerful, but rather those Frostlings who can master these beasts of burden solely through force of will. The ceremony during which these riders are chosen is among the bloodiest spectacles in all of Elemental.

UnitType.Quote: The time of cities is over. The world is ours now.
UnitType.Backstory: Frostling shamans are alternately shunned and revered by their people; they are the oldest, and physically weakest among their tribe, and often scorned for their frailty. Yet the more powerful among them may be respected as well, both for the accumulated wisdom of their years, and for the knowledge they have gained of the channeler's art. All frostlings who become shamans of their tribes can cast Blindness and Icy Blast.

UnitType.Quote: I have survived the trials of Grazna. My skin has turned aside teeth, arrows and spears. I have walked through fire, and ignored winter's fury. What chance do you have against me?
UnitType.Backstory: Bone Ogres are mighty creatures that live in the deepest of volcanic vents, seeking - according to some - a refuge similar to that they are said to have been born and bred in... the underground labryinth of N'it'Vaganesh. Bone Ogres are reclusive and only emerge from their dark, warm caverns on rare occasions. When they do, however, woe to anything and anyone nearby.

It was Curgen's brother, the Drednir known as Kir-Tion, who first summoned these creatures (known variously as Drednii, or Demons) to Elemental. Upon the very altar where Josryn the Elder received Great Ereog's blessing, Kir-Tion first bound and then sacrificed the Princess Lansa to open a portal to the outer planes... and through that portal came these monsters and their brethren (it should be noted that there are some channelers who believe that the Drednii are simply death magic made flesh, and not separate, sentient creatures). All demons draw their strength from devouring the life-force of other beings.
The horns of these creatures are often used in various alchemical remedies and magical experiments, and are extremely valuable.
Through years of deliberate selective breeding the Cult of the Serpent have cultivated this particularly agressive strain of Naja.

Come and play? Yerba are tall, lean humanoids but deceptively strong and quick. Their preferred weapons are daggers and they are very proficient in their use, often wielding one in each hand. Yerba are highly intelligent - most have mastered some of the magical arts and can utilise a number of simple spells.
They are particularly wicked and have a penchant for inflecting pain, most comomonly via knife work. When the opportunity arises their favourite pastime is to take captives back to their lair where they will torture them for days. Predominantly solitary creatures, they tend to hide away to avoid the inevitable witch-hunt that ensues when they are discovered near a town or village. Despite this they are occasssionaly sighted cohabiting with Wildlings - presumably the fact they share a common enjoyment for sticking sharp objects into various parts of the anatomy helps them get along.

UnitType.Backstory:
Sages say the Ophidian were once great pythons, related to the bonefield morelia, but they were changed after generations of nesting near crystal deposits. Those crystals became embedded in their scales. The Ophidian are now over twice as long as their ancestors, and immune to spells. Their bite causes a feeling of numbness and euphoria in the victim; a sensation that helps numb the horror of being swallowed whole.
Those brave enough to capture or kill Ophidian can make a great deal of money selling their scales to enchanters and their venom to those of less repute.

Wargs are fell creatures, wolves mutated by dark magics thousands of years ago. They are stronger and more cunning than their non-magical counterparts. They prefer to hunt alone, and will fight over territory rather than ally themselves with their brethren.
The Fell Warg is the most wicked of the breed; a foul beast that thrives on the blood of it's victims.

These perverted creatures can be found lurking in graveyards and ruins, where they can feed on corpses, carcasses or any other any other flesh they can get their claws on. Some believe their origins can be traced back to a particularly foul tribe of cannibalistic men from the east. The theory has never been substantiated - few scholars of stature are prepared to declare that these hideous creatures are in fact a relative to civilised man.

In Erwynn's Tales, wolves are often found as companions of men. As far back as the Age of the Magi, there are stories of wolf packs accompanying the great armies of men to war. Now though, in the aftermath of the cataclysm, their natural prey has become scarce, and these creatures must be regarded as dangerous by all who encounter them.
Wolf pelts remain rare enough that merchants are still willing to pay a fair price for them.

In Erwynn's Tales, wolves are often found as companions of men. As far back as the Age of the Magi, there are stories of wolf packs accompanying the great armies of men to war. Now though, in the aftermath of the cataclysm, their natural prey has become scarce, and these creatures must be regarded as dangerous by all who encounter them.
Wolf pelts remain rare enough that merchants are still willing to pay a fair price for them.

Now though, in the aftermath of the cataclysm, their natural prey has become scarce, and these creatures must be regarded as dangerous by all who encounter them.
Wolf pelts remain rare enough that merchants are still willing to pay a fair price for them.

The Jungle Weaver spider does not inject venom with its bite, although it can spray a debilitating toxic mist at a short range. It is a stealthy and aggressive hunter, and is known to trap and feed on wolves and even bears.

The Iron Brotherhood is a dangerous gang of scum that preys on those who enter the wilds without protection. While little threat to trained soldiers, they are an effective force for terrorizing isolated settlements
